The first CD was released on June 22, 2005; 29 volumes all together were released.{{cite web|url=http://www.sonymusic.co.jp/Music/Arch/SV/BLEACH/m_disco.html |title=BLEACH : ディスコグラフィ |publisher=[[Sony Music]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=January 1, 2009 }}Aniplex introduced two ''Bleach'' concept albums. The first, ''Bleach Concept Covers'', was released on December 15, 2010, and the second one, ''Bleach Concept Covers 2'', was released on December 14, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.sonymusicshop.jp/m/item/itemShw.php?site=S&ima=3909&cd=SVWC-7733|title=ブリコン　～BLEACH CONCEPT COVERS～|publisher=Sony Music Shop |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 7, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sonymusicshop.jp/m/item/itemShw.php?site=S&ima=4005&cd=SVWC-7799|title=ブリコン ～BLEACH CONCEPT COVERS～ 2【初回限定仕様】|publisher=Sony Music Shop |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 7, 2014}} ===Films=== There are four animated feature films based on the ''Bleach'' series, all of which are directed by [[Noriyuki Abe]], director of the ''Bleach'' anime series. The films were released annually each December starting in 2006, though none were released in 2009. Each movie features an original plotline along with original characters designed by Tite Kubo, which is contrary to the normal practice for anime-based films, as the original author usually has little creative involvement.{{cite AV media notes |title=Bleach: The DiamondDust Rebellion |titlelink=Bleach: The DiamondDust Rebellion |year=2008 |others=[[Noriyuki Abe]] |publisher=[[Toho]] |location=Japan |language=Japanese }} The first film, ''[[Bleach: Memories of Nobody]]'', was released in Japan on December 16, 2006, and had a limited release in American theaters in June 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/japan/yearly/?yr=2006&p=.htm|title=Japan Box Yearly Box Office 2006|accessdate=May 4, 2014|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] }}{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-04-17/first-bleach-film-to-run-in-u.s-theaters-june-11-12|title=First Bleach Film to Run in U.S. Theaters June 11–12|publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=April 17, 2008 |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The movie is centered around the activities of the "Dark Ones," who were banished from the Soul Society and are subsequently trying to destroy both the Soul Society and the World of the Living. ''Memories of Nobody'' was released in North America on [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] [[DVD]] by [[Viz Media]] on October 14, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-1/7665|title=Bleach Movie Video 1|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421013902/http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-1/7665|archivedate=April 21, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The second film, ''[[Bleach: The DiamondDust Rebellion]]'', was released to Japanese theaters on December 22, 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/japan/yearly/?yr=2007&p=.htm|title=Japan Box Yearly Box Office 2007|accessdate=May 4, 2014|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] }} Its plot focuses on 10th Division captain [[Tōshirō Hitsugaya]]'s efforts to clear his name after an artifact belonging to Soul Society's king is stolen while under his care. ''The DiamondDust Rebellion'' was released in North America on Region 1 DVD by Viz Media on September 8, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-2/8364|title=Bleach Movie Video 2|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712051726/http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-2/8364|archivedate=July 12, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The third film, ''[[Bleach: Fade to Black]]'', was released in Japan on December 13, 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/japan/yearly/?yr=2008&p=.htm|title=Japan Box Yearly Box Office 2008|accessdate=May 4, 2014|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}} In the film, members of Soul Society are struck with [[amnesia]], caused by a parasitic Hollow that erases the memories of its victims. The people in those memories forget the victim as well, resulting in everyone losing their memories of Rukia and subsequentially of Ichigo. When he goes to the Soul Society to investigate, Ichigo is hunted as an intruder and the perpetrator of a great disaster and also discovers that Rukia has not only forgotten him, but has forgotten her own identity as well.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-07-15/third-bleach-film-first-major-film-have-titles-dates |title=Third Bleach Film, First Major Film Have Titles, Dates |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=July 15, 2008 |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The film was released on Region 2 DVD on September 30, 2009.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B002F8Q18A/ |title=劇場版BLEACH Fade to Black 君の名を呼ぶ(通常版) [DVD] |publisher=[[Amazon.com|Amazon]] Japan |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The English Dub release of ''Fade to Black'' was released on Region 1 DVD and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] by Viz Media on November 15, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-3/9789|title=Bleach Movie Video 3|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511000644/http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-3/9789|archivedate=May 11, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The fourth movie, ''[[Bleach: Hell Verse]]'', was released in Japan on December 4, 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-07-12/december-bleach/jigoku-hen-film-overseen-by-kubo |title=December's Bleach: Jigoku-Hen Film Overseen by Kubo|publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} In the film, Ichigo is heading into the Gates of Hell, which is where souls and Hollows who had committed evil during their lives as humans are sent. Denizens of Hell, aware of the power of Ichigo's inner Hollow, desire to draw out that power and free themselves from Hell and so they lure Ichigo into the realm by kidnapping his sisters. Tite Kubo did oversee the production of the film.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-09-14/bleach/jigoku-hen-film-yakumo-promos-streamed |title=Bleach: Jigoku-Hen Film, Yakumo Promos Streamed (Updated) - News |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=September 14, 2010 |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The dubbed version was released on Region 1 DVD and Blu-ray by Viz Media on December 4, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-4/10163|title=Bleach Movie Video 4|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712034607/http://www.viz.com/anime/dvd/bleach-movie-video-volume-4/10163|archivedate=July 12, 2014|df=mdy-all}} In March 2010, [[Warner Bros.]] confirmed that it is in talks to create a [[live action|live-action]] movie adaptation of the series. [[Peter Segal]] and Michael Ewing have been lined up to produce the movie.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-03-22/warner-brothers-in-talks-for-live-action-bleach-film|title=Warner Brothers in Film Talks for Bleach Manga |publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} In 2012, [[Dan Mazeau]] was added as a screenwriter for the project, and [[Masi Oka]] joined as producer.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-02-22/warner-develops-live-action-film-of-tite-kubo-bleach-manga|title=Warner Develops Live-Action Film of Tite Kubo's Bleach Manga|work=Anime News Network|accessdate=October 20, 2014}} In 2016, after the series ended, a live-action Japanese adaptation of the series was announced. ''[[Bleach (2018 film)|Bleach]]'', which was produced by Warner Bros. Japan, directed by [[Shinsuke Sato]] and starring [[Sota Fukushi]] as [[Ichigo Kurosaki]], was released in Japan on July 20, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/8/19/12555420/live-action-bleach-movie-in-development-at-warner-bros|title=Live-action Bleach movie in development at Warner Bros.|last=Alexander|first=Julia|date=2016-08-19|website=Polygon|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-20}}{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-08-18/bleach-manga-gets-live-action-film-in-2018-starring-sota-fukushi/.105510|title= Bleach Manga Gets Live-Action Film in 2018 Starring Sōta Fukushi|date= August 18, 2016|accessdate= August 18, 2016|work= [[Anime News Network]]}}{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/daily-briefs/2017-07-06/live-action-bleach-film-opens-in-summer-2018/.118486|title= Live-Action Bleach Film Opens in Summer 2018|date= July 6, 2017|accessdate= July 6, 2017|work= [[Anime News Network]]}} ===Musicals=== {{Main|Rock Musical Bleach}} Bleach has been adapted into a series of rock musicals, jointly produced by [[Studio Pierrot]] and Nelke Planning. There have been five musicals produced which covered portions of the [[List of Bleach episodes (season 1)|Substitute]] and [[List of Bleach episodes (season 2)|Soul Society]] arcs, as well as five additional performances known as "Live Bankai Shows" and "Rock Musical Bleach Shinsei", which did not follow the ''Bleach'' plotline. The initial performance run of the ''Bleach'' musical was from August 17–28, 2005, at the Space Zero Tokyo center in [[Shinjuku, Tokyo|Shinjuku]].{{cite web|url=http://rmbleach.com/|title=Rock Musical Bleach official website|accessdate=May 4, 2014|language=Japanese}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nelke.co.jp/stage/rmbleach/ |title=ロックミュージカル『BLEACH』 |work=Nelke.co.jp |publisher=Nelke Planning Co., LTD |date= |accessdate=May 4, 2014 |language=Japanese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505002634/http://www.nelke.co.jp/stage/rmbleach/ |archivedate=May 5, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-04-11/bleach-rock-musical|title=Bleach Rock Musical|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=April 11, 2005|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The musicals are directed by Takuya Hiramitsu, with script adaptation by Naoshi Okumura and music composed by playwright Shoichi Tama. The songs are completely original and not taken from the anime soundtrack. Key actors in the series include [[Tatsuya Isaka]], who plays [[Ichigo Kurosaki]], [[Miki Satō]], who plays [[Rukia Kuchiki]], and [[Eiji Moriyama]], who plays [[Renji Abarai]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/product/SVWC-7359|title=Rock Musical BLEACH Saien - Live |publisher=CDJapan.co.jp|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} In 2016, another musical was produced to celebrate ''Bleach'' 15th anniversary. The musical was directed and written by Tsutsumi Yasuyuki with [[Dream5]]'s Akira Takano and Chihiro Kai as Ichigo Kurosaki and Rukia Kuchiki respectively. The musical debuted on July 28, 2016 in AiiA 2.5 Theater Tokyo.{{cite web|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|title=New Rock Musical Bleach's Cast, Visual, Debut Date Revealed|accessdate=July 1, 2016|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-05-30/new-rock-musical-bleach-cast-visual-debut-date-revealed/.102639}}{{cite web|publisher=Rock Musical Bleach|title=「ROCK MUSICAL BLEACH」 ～もうひとつの地上～|accessdate=July 1, 2016|url=http://www.rmbleach.com}} ===Trading card game=== {{Main|Bleach Trading Card Game}} Two [[collectible card games]] (CCG) based on the ''Bleach'' series have been produced, one in the Japanese market and a different one in North America. ''Bleach Soul Card Battle'', produced by [[Bandai]], was introduced in Japan in 2004.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0007CVJ38/ |title=BLEACH :SOUL CARD BATTLE.1 構築済みスターターセット 友情デッキ |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] Japan |accessdate=May 6, 2014}} Twenty named sets were released for the series.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0027P8TAE/ |title=BLEACH SOUL CARD BATTLE March Of The Death (20) ブースターパック BOX |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] Japan |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 6, 2014}} After ''Bleach Soul Card Battle'', Bandai introduced three more series. ''Bleach The Card Gum'', which contains 14 sets, was released in early September 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.bandai.co.jp/catalog/item/4543112496447000.html |title=Bleach The Card Gum 1 |publisher=[[Bandai]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 9, 2014}} The next series, ''Bleach Clear Collection'', which contains six sets, was released in July 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.carddass.com/bleach/cardlist_cc6.html |title=Bleach Clear Collection 6 |publisher=[[Carddass]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 7, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528030142/http://www.carddass.com/bleach/cardlist_cc6.html |archivedate=May 28, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} The last series, ''Bleach Clear Soul Plate'', which consists of three sets, was published in December 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.carddass.com/bleach/product_csp3.html |title=Bleach Clear Soul Plate 3 |publisher=[[Carddass]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 7, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202040302/http://www.carddass.com/bleach/product_csp3.html |archivedate=February 2, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} ''Bleach TCG'' was introduced in the United States by [[Score Entertainment]] in May 2007,{{cite web |url=http://www.officialbleachtcg.com/faq.cfm#promo |title=Official Bleach TCG: FAQ |publisher=[[Score Entertainment]] |accessdate=November 2, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217153219/http://www.officialbleachtcg.com/faq.cfm#promo |archivedate=December 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes }} but ceased publication April 2009, just before the planned launch of its seventh expansion, ''Bleach Infiltration''.{{cite web |url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/14681.html |title='Bleach TCG' RIP |publisher=icv2 |accessdate=May 22, 2009}} This cancellation was attributed to the [[Late-2000s recession|ongoing recession]], which has heavily affected TCG sales. Designed by Aik Tongtharadol, the TCG is a two-player game in which each player starts with at least 61 cards: a "Guardian" card, a 60-card "main deck," and an optional 20-card "side deck." A player loses if his or her power, as dictated by the Guardian card, is reduced to zero, or if he or she is unable to draw or discard a card from his or her deck.{{cite web |url=http://www.officialbleachtcg.com/rules.cfm |title=Official Bleach TCG: Rules |publisher=[[Score Entertainment]] |accessdate=November 2, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217075805/http://www.officialbleachtcg.com/rules.cfm |archivedate=December 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes }} The cards for the game have been released in named sets with each set released in three formats: a 72-card pre-constructed box set containing a [[Starter pack|starter deck]] and two [[booster pack]]s, a 10-card booster pack, and a 12-pack booster box. Six named sets were released.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00168T6RS/ |title=Bleach Trading Card Game - Bankai Starter Deck|publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |accessdate=July 21, 2009}} ===Video games=== {{See also|List of Bleach video games}} A number of video games have been created featuring characters from the ''Bleach'' series, primarily though not exclusively [[fighting game]]s. The first video game to be released from the ''Bleach'' series was ''Bleach: Heat the Soul'', which debuted on March 24, 2005, for the [[Sony]] [[PlayStation Portable]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/games/bleach-heat-the-soul/psp-714494|title=IGN: ''Bleach: Heat the Soul'' |publisher=IGN|date=|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} Currently, the majority of the games have only been released in Japan, though [[Sega]] has localized the first three [[Nintendo DS]] games and the first Wii game for North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/07/28/bleach-2nd-details|title=Bleach 2nd Details|author=Gantayat, Anoop|publisher=IGN|date=July 28, 2006|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} So far, all dedicated ''Bleach'' games released for [[Sony]]'s consoles have been developed and published by [[Sony Computer Entertainment|SCEI]], whereas the games for [[Nintendo]] consoles are developed and published by Sega, and the Nintendo DS games are developed by [[Treasure (company)|Treasure Co. Ltd.]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/games/bleach-the-blade-of-fate/nds-763827|title=IGN: Bleach: The Blade of Fate|publisher=IGN|date=|accessdate=May 4, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/games/bleach-shattered-blade/wii-833630|title=IGN: Bleach: Shattered Blade|publisher=IGN|date=|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} Two [[mobile game]]s had also been released in 2014 and 2016 for the series, which are available for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]].{{cite web|url=http://corp.gree.net/jp/ja/news/press/2014/0414-01.html|title=グリーとORATTAの共同開発タイトル「BLEACH 卍解バトル」4月14日より提供開始|publisher=GREE, Inc.|language=Japanese|date=April 14, 2014|accessdate=May 2, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.klab.com/jp/press/150723.html|title=KLab、爽快3Dアクションゲーム「BLEACH Brave Souls」App StoreおよびGoogle Play向けに配信開始！|publisher=KLab Inc.|language=Japanese|date=July 23, 2015|accessdate=October 7, 2015}} In 2017, [[Line Corporation|Line]] announced the release of a game exclusive for their communication app called ''Bleach: Paradise Lost''.{{cite web|url=http://gamestalk.net/post-82913/|title=LINE GAMEに『BLEACH』の最新ゲームが登場！GPSを使って遊ぶRPG作品|publisher=Gamer'sTalk.net|language=Japanese|date=July 27, 2017|accessdate=July 29, 2017}} ===Light novels=== [[Tite Kubo]] and Makoto Matsubara have co-authored three novelizations of the ''Bleach'' series, which were published by [[Shueisha]] under its ''Shounen Jump Books'' label. The first volume, ''Bleach - Letters From The Other Side: The Death and The Strawberry'', was published on December 15, 2004, and re-released as ''Bleach - Letters From The Other Side: The Death and The Strawberry - New Edition'' on November 4, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=4-08-703149-7|title=BLEACH-letters from the other side: The Death and The Strawberry |language=Japanese|publisher=[[Shueisha]] |accessdate=May 4, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-703212-3|title=BLEACH-letters from the other side: The Death and The Strawberry -new　edition-|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Shueisha]] |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The second, ''Bleach: The Honey Dish Rhapsody'', was published on November 30, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=4-08-703173-X |title=Bleach: The Honey Dish Rhapsody |language=Japanese|publisher=[[Shueisha]] |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The third, ''Bleach: The Death Save The Strawberry'', was published on September 4, 2012.{{cite web |url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-703272-7|title=Bleach: The Death Save The Strawberry|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Shueisha]] |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} Two novelizations of the ''Bleach'' series, have been co-authored by [[Ryohgo Narita|Narita Ryohgo]]. The first volume, ''Bleach: Spirits Are Forever With You'', and the second, ''Bleach: Spirits Are Forever With You 2'', were published on June 4, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-703265-9|title=BLEACH: Spirits Are Forever With You I|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 3, 2014|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-703266-6|title=BLEACH: Spirits Are Forever With You II|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 3, 2014|language=Japanese}} After the series ended in 2016, a series of novels were released by Shueisha.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-12-08/more-details-revealed-for-2-upcoming-bleach-novels/.109645|title=More Details Revealed For 2 Upcoming Bleach Novels|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=May 28, 2017|language=English}} The first novel, ''Bleach: WE DO knot ALWAYS LOVE YOU'', is written by the writer of ''Bleach: The Death Save The Strawberry'' and was published on December 27, 2016. The second, ''Bleach: Can't Fear Your Own World'', is a serialized novel written by the writer of ''Bleach: Spirits Are Forever With You'' series and is released bi-weekly from April 28, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-04-22/ryohgo-narita-new-bleach-novel-reveals-title-digital-serialization-starting-on-april-28/.115160|title=Ryohgo Narita's New Bleach Novel Reveals Title, Digital Serialization Starting on April 28|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=May 28, 2017|language=English}}{{cite web|url=http://comicbook.com/anime/2017/04/25/bleach-anime-manga-tite-kubo-soul-society/|title=Bleach’s New Canon Spin-Off Novel Releases Story Details|publisher=Comicbook.com|accessdate=May 28, 2017|language=English}} The first volume was released on August 4, 2017{{cite web |last1=Kelly |first1=Rai |title=Bleach: Can't Fear Your Own World Novels Go On Hiatus |url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-07-21/bleach-cant-fear-your-own-world-novels-go-on-hiatus/.119177 |website=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=October 30, 2018 |date=July 21, 2017}} and the second volume was published on November 2, 2018. The novel series ended with the release of the third volume on December 4, 2018.{{cite web |last1=Pineda |first1=Rafael Antonio |title=Bleach Novel Series to End With 3rd Volume |url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-10-29/bleach-novel-series-to-end-with-3rd-volume/.138754 |website=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=October 30, 2018 |date=October 29, 2018}} Shueisha published four novelizations based on the ''Bleach'' movies. The first volume, ''Bleach: Memories of Nobody'', was published on December 18, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=4-08-703174-8|title=劇場版BLEACH　　 ―MEMORIES　OF　NOBODY―|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 6, 2014|language=Japanese}} The second, ''Bleach: The DiamondDust Rebellion, Another Hyōrinmaru'', was published on December 22, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-703189-8|title=劇場版　BLEACH　　 The　DiamondDust　Rebellion　もう一つの氷輪丸|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 6, 2014|language=Japanese}} The third, ''Bleach: Fade to Black, I Call Your Name'', was published on December 15, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-703197-3|title=劇場版BLEACH　　 Fade　to　Black　君の名を呼ぶ|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 6, 2014|language=Japanese}} The fourth volume, ''Bleach: Hell Chapter'', was published on December 6, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-703234-5|title=劇場版BLEACH　　 地獄篇|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 6, 2014|language=Japanese}} ===Other=== The first ''Bleach'' artbook, ''All Colour But The Black'', has been released in Japan, the United States, and Europe. The artbook compiles a selection of color spreads from the first 19 volumes of the series, as well as some original art and author commentary.{{cite web |url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=4-08-874173-0|title=BLEACHイラスト集 All Colour But The Black|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/books/print/art-of-bleach-volume-1/7223|title=The Art of Bleach|publisher=[[Viz media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504191814/http://www.viz.com/books/print/art-of-bleach-volume-1/7223|archivedate=May 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The second artbook, {{Nihongo|''Bleach Official Bootleg: KaraBuri+''|BLEACH OFFICIAL BOOTLEG カラブリ プラス}}, was released on August 3, 2007. In addition to character guides and articles on other fictional aspects of the series, it compiles the various short comics, {{Nihongo|Tedious Everyday Tales Colorful Bleach|徒然日常絵詞 カラフル ブリーチ|Tsuredure Nichijou Ekotoba Karafuru Buriichi}}, that were published in ''[[V Jump]]''. The ''[[omake]]''-style panels are similar to those included in the main series, but reveal more of the daily lives of characters.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-874199-4|title=BLEACH OFFICIAL BOOTLEG カラブリ+|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|language=Japanese}} ''Color Bleach+: Bleach Official Bootleg'' was released in English by Viz Media on August 10, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/books/print/color-bleach-bleach-official-bootleg-volume-1/8757|title=Color Bleach+: Bleach Official Bootleg|publisher=[[Viz media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504204559/http://www.viz.com/books/print/color-bleach-bleach-official-bootleg-volume-1/8757|archivedate=May 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}} In December 2018, another artbook will be released, which will contain a massive 700 artworks from the series' 15 years tenure. It will be titled ''Bleach JET''.{{cite web |url=http://comicbook.com/anime/2018/06/04/bleach-art-collection-announced-anime-manga/|title='Bleach' Announces Massive Art Collection|publisher=Comicbook.com|accessdate=June 12, 2018|language=English}} Seven databooks have also been released about the series. The first two, ''Bleach: Official Character Book SOULs.'' and ''Bleach: Official Animation Book VIBEs.'', were released on February 3, 2006.{{cite web |url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=4-08-874079-3|title=BLEACH―ブリーチ― OFFICIAL CHARACTER BOOK SOULs. |publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|language=Japanese}}{{cite web |url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=4-08-874080-7 |title=BLEACH―ブリーチ― OFFICIAL ANIMATION BOOK VIBEs. |publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|language=Japanese}} ''Bleach: Official Character Book SOULs.'' was later released in English by Viz Media on November 18, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/books/print/bleach-souls-official-character-book-volume-1/7403|title=Bleach SOULs. Official Character Book|publisher=[[Viz media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504190544/http://www.viz.com/books/print/bleach-souls-official-character-book-volume-1/7403|archivedate=May 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The third book, ''Bleach: Official Character Book 2: MASKED'', was released on August 4, 2010. This book covers details about characters that appear 100 years prior to the story, such as former captains and lieutenants, along with the Arrancars and Visoreds. Although it was released on the same day as volume 46, ''Back From Blind'', the book only covers material up to volume 37, ''Beauty Is So Solitary''.{{cite web |url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-874845-0|title=BLEACH―ブリーチ― OFFICIAL CHARACTER BOOK 2 MASKED. |publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|language=Japanese}} The English version was released by Viz Media on March 6, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.viz.com/books/print/bleach-masked-official-character-book-2/10109|title=Bleach MASKED: Official Character Book 2|publisher=[[Viz media]]|accessdate=May 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504192255/http://www.viz.com/books/print/bleach-masked-official-character-book-2/10109|archivedate=May 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}} A fourth book ''Bleach: Official Invitation Book The Hell Verse'', was published on December 4, 2010. This book was released to promote ''Bleach'' movie:''Hell Verse'' and it contains character sketches, promotional posters and the one-off Hell manga special.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/BLEACH-%E3%83%96%E3%83%AA%E3%83%BC%E3%83%81-%E5%85%A5%E5%A0%B4%E8%80%85%E7%89%B9%E5%85%B8%E3%82%B3%E3%83%9F%E3%83%83%E3%82%AF-INVITATION-Verse/dp/B00AXKFXPO|title=劇場版 BLEACH ブリーチ 地獄編 入場者特典コミック 【 INVITATION BOOK The Hell Verse 】|publisher=[[Amazon.com]] Japan|language=Japanese|accessdate=May 6, 2014}} A fifth book ''Bleach: Official Character Book 3: UNMASKED'', was released on June 3, 2011, the same day as the volume 50 of the series. However it only covers material up to volume 48, ''God is Dead''.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-874861-0|title=Bleach: Official Character Book 3: UNMASKED|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} On June 4, 2012, a sixth book has been released under the name ''Bleach: The Rebooted Souls''. This free booklet has been distributed with ''Bleach'' manga volume 55, with the aim to provide information to readers about upcoming manga's final arc, ''The Thousand-Year Blood War''.{{cite web|url=http://www.s-manga.net/comics_new/cn_20120604_wj_jpc_bleach-the-rebooted-souls_hhjAYx2E.html|title=BLEACH: THE REBOOTED SOULS|publisher=s-manga.net|language=Japanese|accessdate=May 6, 2014}} The seventh book, ''BLEACH 13 BLADEs.'', was released on August 4, 2015 and focused solely on the Soul Reapers and the 13 Court Squads.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/BLEACH-13-BLADEs-ジャンプコミックス-久保帯人/dp/4088805259/ref=sr_1_14?ie=UTF8&qid=1496002943&sr=8-14&keywords=BLEACH|title=BLEACH 13 BLADEs. (ジャンプコミックス)|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=May 28, 2017}} Shueisha published a special book ''Bleach: JCCover Postcard Book MAILs.'', which was released on December 4, 2013. It features cover pages as postcards up to volume 60 with poems on the back.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-880089-9|title=BLEACH: JCCOVER　POSTCARD　BOOK MAILs．|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=May 4, 2014}} ==Reception== [[File:Otakuthon 2014- Bleach (14850595510).jpg|thumb|right|300px|Fans dressed as characters from ''Bleach'', pictured in 2014.]] ''Bleach'' has sold over 90{{nbsp}}million [[tankobon]] copies in Japan, and over 120 million tankobon copies worldwide, making it the 6th best-selling series of all time from ''Weekly Shōnen Jump''. In 2005, ''Bleach'' was awarded the [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] in the ''shōnen'' category.{{cite web|url=http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |script-title=ja:小学館漫画賞: 歴代受賞者 |publisher=[[Shogakukan]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=August 19, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217065029/http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |archivedate=December 17, 2008 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url=http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |script-title=ja:の作品はオンラインで購入することができます |publisher=[[Shogakukan]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=December 14, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217065029/http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |archivedate=December 17, 2008 |df=mdy }} During 2008, volume 34 of the manga sold 874,153 copies in Japan, becoming the 12th best-seller comics from the year. Volumes 33 and 35 have also ranked 17 and 18, respectively.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-12-19/2008-yearly-japanese-comic-ranking-no.1-25|title=2008's Top-Selling Manga in Japan, #1-25|publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=December 19, 2008 |accessdate=December 30, 2008 }} In total the manga has sold 3,161,825 copies in Japan during 2008, becoming the year's 5th best selling series.{{cite web | title=2008's Top-Selling Manga in Japan, by Series|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2009-01-02/2008-top-selling-manga-in-japan-by-series|date=January 2, 2009 | publisher=[[Anime News Network]]| accessdate=January 3, 2009}} In the first half from 2009, ''Bleach'' ranked as the 2nd best-selling manga in Japan, having sold 3.5 million copies.{{cite web | title=Top-Selling Manga in Japan by Series: 1st Half of 2009|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2009-06-15/top-selling-manga-in-japan-by-series/1st-half-of-2009|date=June 15, 2009 | publisher=[[Anime News Network]]| accessdate=June 15, 2009}} Having sold 927,610 copies, Volume 36 ranked 7th. Volume 37 was 8th with 907,714 sold copies, and volume 38 at 10th with 822,238 copies.{{cite web | title=Top-Selling Manga in Japan by Volume: 1st Half of 2009 (Updated)|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2009-06-15/top-selling-manga-in-japan-by-volume/1st-half-of-2009|date=June 15, 2009 | publisher=[[Anime News Network]]| accessdate=June 15, 2009}} North American sales of the manga have also been high, with tankobon volumes having sold over 1.2{{nbsp}}million copies by 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2009-09-01/viz-release-bleach-the-movie-diamonddust-rebellion |title=Viz To Release Bleach The Movie 2: The DiamondDust Rebellion on DVD |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=September 1, 2007 |accessdate=September 28, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2008-05-21/viz-media-shonen-jump-welcomes-bleach-manga-creator-tite-kubo-for-ultra-rare-appearance-at-2008-san-diego-comic-con-international |title=Viz Media's Shonen Jump Welcomes Bleach Manga Creator Tite Kubo for Ultra-Rare Appearance at 2008 San Diego Comic-Con International |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=May 21, 2008 |accessdate=September 28, 2009}} Volume 16 placing in the top 10 graphic novel sales in December 2006 and volume 17 being the best-selling manga volume for the month of February 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/9908.html |title=Top 100 Graphic Novels Actual--December 2006 |publisher=ICv2 |date=January 16, 2007 |accessdate=March 28, 2007 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/10271.html |title=Top 100 Graphic Novels Actual--February 2007 |publisher=ICv2 |date=March 20, 2007 |accessdate=March 28, 2007 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/10272.html |title=Civil War Finale Tops the Charts |publisher=ICv2 |date=March 20, 2007 |accessdate=March 28, 2007 }} In a 2010 interview, Gonzalo Ferreyra, Vice President of Sales and Marketing for Viz, listed ''Bleach'' as one of six Viz titles that continue to exceed expectations in spite of the harshening manga market.{{cite web | publisher = ICv2 | date =January 21, 2010 | title = Interview with Viz's Gonzalo Ferreyra, Part 1|accessdate= January 21, 2010|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/16702.html}} The English version of the manga was nominated for the "best manga" and "best theme" awards at the 2006 and 2007 [[American Anime Awards]], but did not win either category.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2007-02-07/american-anime-awards-finalists-announced |title=American Anime Awards Finalists Announced |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=February 2, 2007 |accessdate=September 28, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2007-02-07/american-anime-awards-finalists-announced |title=American Anime Awards Winners |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=February 24, 2007 |accessdate=September 28, 2009}} Deb Aoki from [[About.com]] considered the series as the Best Continuing Shōnen Manga of 2007, along with ''[[Eyeshield 21]]'', praising the "compelling stories, dazzling action sequences and great character development".{{cite web |url=http://manga.about.com/od/recommendedreading/tp/2007BestManga.htm |title=2007 Best Continuing Manga List — Top 10 Current Manga Series of 2007 |publisher=[[About.com]] |last=Aoki |first=Deb |year=2007 |accessdate=December 13, 2008}} She also placed the title on her list of "Top 10 Shōnen Manga Must-Reads".{{cite web |url=http://manga.about.com/od/recommendedreading/tp/top10shonen.htm |title=Recommended Reading — Top 10 List of Shōnen Manga Must-Reads |publisher=[[About.com]] |last=Aoki |first=Deb |accessdate=December 13, 2008}} The artwork and the character designs received positive response by [[IGN]]'s A.E. Sparrow. He also commented on the series' ability to handle multiple minor character plotlines at the same time, which he considered a point of appeal, in response to fans' claims about a "lack of a story" in ''Bleach''.{{cite web|url=http://comics.ign.com/articles/772/772283p1.html|title=Bleach: Volume 18 review Blink and you'll miss something very cool|author=Sparrow, A. E.|publisher=IGN|date=March 12, 2007|accessdate=November 1, 2008}} Leroy Douresseaux from ComicBookBin agreed with Sparrow in the number of storylines, but also praised the fighting scenes finding them comparable to the ones of popular films.{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookbin.com/bleach022.html|title=Bleach: Volume 22 review |author=Douresseaux, Leroy|publisher=comicbookbin.com|date=January 27, 2007|accessdate=November 1, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookbin.com/bleach022.html|title=Bleach: Volume 20 review |author=Douresseaux, Leroy|publisher=comicbookbin.com|date=July 22, 2007|accessdate=November 1, 2008}} On the other hand, Mania reviewer Jarred Pine criticized the series as being plagued with stereotypes from the genre. He felt it was a rough start for the series with unimpressive battles, overused gags, and a bad introduction for central character Ichigo that causes him to come across "as a frowning punk" whose one good trait is his desire to protect. Despite this, Pine notes that he loves the series, particularly its quirky, lovable characters.{{cite web |url=http://www.mania.com/bleach-vol-01_article_82089.html |title=Bleach Vol. #01 |date=February 24, 2005 |publisher=Mania |last=Pine |first=Jarred |accessdate=December 13, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018201823/http://www.mania.com/bleach-vol-01_article_82089.html |archivedate=October 18, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} [[Jason Thompson (writer)|Jason Thompson]] said he was no longer able to take ''Bleach'' seriously after it introduced villains [[Ulquiorra]] and [[Yammy]] in a scene precisely mirroring [[Vegeta]] and [[Nappa (character)|Nappa]]'s arrival in ''[[Dragon Ball|Dragon Ball Z]]'', but acknowledged it was likely intended as a deliberate homage. He also said Kubo was able to avoid the worst artistic failings typical in series which indulge in superpowered combat, but that the battle scenes were still sometimes difficult to follow.{{cite web |url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/house-of-1000-manga/2013-01-31|title=Jason Thompson's House of 1000 Manga - The Saga of Shonen Jump Part II|publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |last=Thompson |first=Jason |date=2013-01-31 |accessdate=2014-08-15}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote|Bleach (manga)}} {{Commons category|Bleach (manga)}} * [http://www.j-bleach.com/ Official website] {{ja icon}} * [http://bleach.viz.com/ Official Viz Media ''Bleach'' website] * [http://www.shonenjump.com/j/rensai/bleach.html Official Japan Shonen Jump ''Bleach'' website] {{ja icon}} * {{ann|manga|2468|Bleach}} {{Bleach}} {{Weekly Shōnen Jump - 2000-2009}} {{Shogakukan Manga Award - Shōnen}} [[Category:2001 manga]] [[Category:2016 comics endings]] [[Category:Bleach (manga)]] [[Category:Adventure anime and manga]] [[Category:Fiction about the afterlife]] [[Category:Artificial mythology]] [[Category:Manga adapted into films]] [[Category:Manga adapted into television series]] [[Category:Masks in fiction]] [[Category:Musicals based on anime and manga]] [[Category:Fiction about the paranormal]] [[Category:Shinigami in anime and manga]] [[Category:Shōnen manga]] [[Category:Shueisha manga]] [[Category:Supernatural anime and manga]] [[Category:Viz Media manga]] [[Category:Winners of the Shogakukan Manga Award for shōnen manga]]

{{short description|Torture device used for capital punishment}} {{other uses of|Catherine wheel}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{refimprove|date=January 2018}} [[File:17XX Richtrad anagoria.JPG|thumb|Execution wheel (German: ''Richtrad'') with underlays, 18th century; on display at the [[Märkisches Museum]], Berlin]] The '''breaking wheel''' or '''execution wheel''', also known as the '''Catherine wheel''' or simply the '''Wheel''', was a [[Torture|torture method]] used for [[Capital punishment#Public execution|public execution]] from [[Classical antiquity|antiquity]] through [[Middle Ages]] into the [[early modern period]] by breaking a criminal's bones and/or [[Club (weapon)|bludgeoning]] them to death. The practice was abolished in [[Bavaria]] in 1813 and in the [[Electorate of Hesse]] in 1836: the last known execution by the "Wheel" took place in [[Prussia]] in 1841. In the [[Holy Roman Empire]], it was a "[[mirror punishment]]" for [[highwaymen]] and [[Footpad|street thieves]] but was also set out in the ''[[Sachsenspiegel]]'' for [[murder]] and [[arson]].<ref name="MSK">{{Cite book|title=Menschen im Schatten der Kathedrale: Neuigkeiten aus dem Mittelalter|trans-title=People in the shadow of the cathedral: News from the Middle Ages|url=|last1=Althoff|first1=Gerd|last2=Goetz|first2=Hans-Werner|last3=Schubert|first3=Ernst|authorlink=|publisher=Wissenschaftliche Buchgesellschaft|location= Darmstadt|date=1998|page=332|language=German|volume=|isbn=9783534142217}}</ref>
==Punishment== ===Execution by wheel=== [[File:Klassisches Radern.png|thumb|Illustration of execution by wheel ([[Augsburg]], Bavaria, 1586): Classic example of the "breaking wheel" punishment, with wheel crucifixions in the background]] [[File:Städtisches museum zittau - 44.jpg|right|thumb|An execution wheel (German: ''Richtrad'') exhibited in the Museum of Cultural History Franziskanerkloster in [[Zittau]], Saxony, Germany, dated in the centre with year 1775. Bolted to the lower rim edge is an iron blade-like thrust attachment]] Those convicted as [[Murder|murderers]] and/or [[Robbery|robbers]] to be executed by "the Wheel", sometimes termed to be "Wheeled" or "broken by the Wheel", would be taken to a public stage [[Scaffold (execution site)|scaffold]] site and tied to the floor. The execution Wheel was typically a large wooden spoked wheel, the same as was used on wooden transport carts and [[carriages]] (often with [[iron]] rim), sometimes purposely modified with a rectangular iron thrust attached and extending blade-like from part of the rim. The primary goal of the first act was the agonizing mutilation of the body, not death. Therefore, the most common form would start with breaking the [[leg bones]]. To this end, the [[executioner]] dropped the execution Wheel on the [[Tibia|shinbones]] of the convicted person and then worked his way up to the arms. Here, rhythm and number of beatings were prescribed in each case, sometimes also the number of spokes on the Wheel. To increase its effect, often sharp-edged timbers were placed under the convict's [[joints]]. Later, there were devices in which the convicted person could be "harnessed". Although not commonplace, the executioner could be instructed to execute the convicted person at the end of the first act, by aiming for the neck or heart in a "[[Coup de grâce|coup de grace]]". Even less often, this occurred immediately from the start (from the head down).<ref name="DGDG">{{Cite book|title=Die Geschichte der Gerichtsbarkeit: vom Gottesurteil bis zum Beginn der modernen Rechtsprechung ; 1000 Jahre Grausamkeit ; Hintergründe, Urteile, Aberglaube, Hexen, Folter, Tod|trans-title=The history of the judicature: from the judgment of God to the beginning of modern jurisprudence; 1000 years of cruelty; Backgrounds, judgments, superstition, witches, torture, death|url=|first=Wolfgang|last=Schild|authorlink=|publisher=Nikol Verlagsgesellschaft mbH|location=Hamburg|date=1997|page=202|language=German|volume=|isbn=9783930656745}}</ref>
In the second act, the body was braided into another wooden spoked wheel, which was possible through the broken limbs, or tied to the wheel. The wheel was then erected on a mast or pole, like a [[crucifixion]]. After this, the executioner was permitted to [[Decapitation|decapitate]] or [[garrotte]] the convicted if need be. Alternatively, fire was kindled under the Wheel, or the "Wheeled" convict was simply thrown into a fire. Occasionally, a small [[gallows]] was set up on the Wheel, for example, if the guilty verdict in addition to murder was by theft.<ref name="DGDG" />
Since the body remained on the Wheel after execution, left to scavenging animals, birds and decay, this form of punishment, like the ancient [[crucifixion]], had a sacral function beyond death: According to the belief at that time, this would hinder transition from death to [[resurrection]].<ref name="MSK" />{{rp|180}}
If the convict fell from the Wheel still alive or the execution failed in some other way, it was interpreted as [[God]]'s intervention. There exist [[Votive offering|votive images]] of saved victims of the Wheel, and there is literature on how best to treat such sustained injuries.<ref name="DGDG" />{{rp|204}}
The survival time after being "wheeled" or "broken" could be extensive. Accounts exist of a 14th-century murderer who remained conscious for three days after undergoing the punishment.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uOUyAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA162|pages=162–163|last=Sporschil|first=Johann|title=Geschichte des Entstehens: des Wachsthums und der Grösse der österreichischen Monarchie|volume=2|year=1847|location=Leipzig|publisher=Oscar Banckwitz}}</ref> In 1348, during the time of the [[Black Death]], a Jewish man named Bona Dies underwent the punishment. The authorities stated he remained conscious for four days and nights afterwards.<ref>{{cite book|pages=211|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1O_PX2wVD0sC&pg=PA211|title=The Black Death|last=Horrox|first=Rosemay|year=1994|publisher=Manchester University Press|location=Manchester|isbn=9780719034985}}</ref> In 1581, the possibly fictitious German [[serial killer]] [[Christman Genipperteinga]] remained conscious for nine days on the breaking wheel before expiring, having been deliberately kept alive with "strong drink".<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dJBSAAAAcAAJ&hl=en |last=Herber |first=Caspar |title=Erschröckliche newe Zeytung Von einem Mörder Christman genant, welcher ist Gericht worden zu Bergkessel den 17. Juny diß 1581 Jars |year=1581 |location=Mainz}} </ref>
Alternatively, the condemned were spreadeagled and broken on a [[saltire]], a cross consisting of two wooden beams nailed in an "X" shape,<ref>{{cite book | last = Abbott | first = Geoffrey | title = What A Way To Go | publisher = St. Martin's Griffin | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-0-312-36656-8 | location = New York | page = 36}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Kerrigan | first = Michael | title = The Instruments of Torture | publisher = Lyons Press | date = 2007 | location = Guilford, Connecticut | isbn = 978-1-59921-127-5 | page = 180}}</ref> after which the victim's mangled body might be displayed on the wheel.<ref>{{cite book | last = Abbott | first = Geoffrey | title = What A Way To Go | publisher = St. Martin's Griffin | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-0-312-36656-8 | location = New York | pages = 40–41, 47}}</ref>
==History==
===Possible Frankish origins=== Pieter Spierenburg mentions a reference in sixth-century author [[Gregory of Tours]] as a possible origin for the punishment of breaking someone on the wheel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norberteliasfoundation.nl/network/profile.php?profId=3|title=Pieter Spierenburg|work=Norbert Elias Foundation}}</ref> In Gregory's time, a criminal could be placed in a deep track, and then a heavily laden wagon was driven over him. Thus, the latter practice could be seen as a symbolic re-enactment of the previous penalty in which people were literally driven over by a wagon.<ref>{{cite book|last=Spierenburg|first=Pieter C.|title=The Spectacle of Suffering: Executions and the Evolution of Repression : from a Preindustrial Metropolis to the European Experience|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NxQ-AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA71|pages=71|year=1984|isbn=9780521261869}}</ref>
===France=== In France, the condemned were placed on a cartwheel with their limbs stretched out along the spokes over two sturdy wooden beams. The wheel was made to revolve slowly, and a large [[hammer]] or an iron bar was then applied to the limb over the gap between the beams, breaking the [[bone]]s. This process was repeated several times per limb. Sometimes it was "mercifully" ordered that the executioner should strike the condemned on the chest and abdomen, blows known as {{lang|fr|[[Coup de grâce|coups de grâce]]}} ({{lang-fr|"blows of mercy"}}), which caused fatal injuries. Without those, the broken man could last hours and even days, during which birds could peck at the helpless victim. Eventually, [[Shock (circulatory)|shock]] and [[dehydration]] caused death. In France, a special grace, the ''retentum'', could be granted, by which the condemned was strangled after the second or third blow, or in special cases, even before the breaking began.
===Holy Roman Empire=== [[Image:Klostermayr Radbrechmaschine.jpg|thumb|Breaking-wheel machine used to execute [[Matthias Klostermayr]], Bavaria, 1772.]] In the [[Holy Roman Empire]], the wheel was punishment reserved primarily for men convicted of aggravated murder (murder committed during another crime, or against a family member). Less severe offenders would be cudgelled "top down", with a lethal first blow to the neck. More heinous criminals were punished "bottom up", starting with the legs, and sometimes being beaten for hours. The number and sequence of blows was specified in the court's sentence (for example, in 1581, the arch-killer [[Peter Niers]], found guilty of 544 murders was, after two days of extended torture, given 42 strikes with the wheel, and was, at last, [[Dismemberment|quartered]] alive<ref>{{cite book|last=Garon|first=Louis|title=Exilium melancholiae|publisher=Josias Städel|location=Strasbourg|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k1hCAAAAcAAJ|pages=553|year=1669}}</ref>). Corpses were left for [[carrion]]-eaters, and the criminals' heads often placed on a spike.<ref>{{cite book |last=Evans |first=Richard J. |title=Rituals of Retribution: Capital Punishment in Germany 1600–1987 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |publication-place=USA |date=9 May 1996 |page=29 |isbn=978-0-19-821968-2 }}</ref>
The "Zürcher Blutgerichtsordnung" (Procedures for the [[Blood Court]] in [[Zurich]]) dates from the 15th century and contains a detailed description of how the breaking on the wheel shall occur: Firstly, the delinquent is placed belly down, bound hands and feet outstretched to a board, and thus dragged by a horse to the place of execution. The wheel is then slammed two times on each arm, one blow above the elbow, the other below. Then, each leg gets the same treatment, above and below the knees. The final ninth blow is given at the middle of the spine, so that it breaks. Then, the broken body is woven onto the wheel (i.e., between the spokes), and the wheel is then hammered onto a pole, which is then fastened upright in its other end in the ground. The criminal is then to be left dying "afloat" on the wheel, and be left to rot.<ref>{{cite book|last=Müller|first=J.|title=Der Aargau: Seine politische, Rechts-, Kultur- und Sitten-Geschichte. ¬Der alte Aarau, Volume 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9EdCAAAAcAAJ|year=1870|publisher=Schultheß|location=Zurich|pages=385–86|accessdate=24 March 2013}}</ref>
====Dolle case; unclear case ==== On 1 October 1786 in the [[County of Tecklenburg]], Heinrich Dolle was to be executed by being broken on the wheel, on account of the aggravated murder of a Jew. The court had decided that Dolle should be broken ''von oben herab'': the first stroke of the wheel should crush his chest (traditionally thought to kill him instantly). The court instructed the executioner, Essmeyer, that Dolle should be clandestinely strangled (by [[garrotte]]) prior to the first stroke. The bystanders were shocked by what they thought was a severely botched execution by Essmeyer and his son, and thought Dolle had been alive during the entire proceeding, and also after Essmeyer had secured Dolle onto the wheel, and raised it on a pole. The town physician climbed up on a ladder (the Essmeyers had gone by then), and could ascertain that Dolle was indeed alive; he died six hours later.{{cn|date=July 2017}}
The Essmeyers were taken to court for severe malpractice. It was established that the string around Dolle's neck had not been drawn tightly enough, and that Essmeyer had, contrary to his duties as an executioner, accepted the use of a wheel that was not heavy enough. That lacking weight meant that the chest had not been crushed. Furthermore, one arm and one leg of Dolle's had not broken according to proper penal procedure. And finally, the nail that was customarily hammered through the convict's brain in order to fasten him upon the wheel had been hammered in far too low.{{cn|date=July 2017}} Many believed that Essmeyer's act of malpractice had been not so much a display of gross incompetence as it had been a deliberate act of cruelty because Dolle, just prior to his execution, had converted from Catholicism to that of the Reformed Church (the executioner Essmeyer was a devout Catholic). The court did not find sufficient evidence for deliberate malice on Essmeyer's part, but sentenced him to two years' hard labour and banned him from ever working again as an executioner. His young son was, on grounds of mercy, acquitted of any culpable wrongdoings.<ref>{{cite book|last=Klein|first=Ernst F.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=An1DAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA35|pages=35–41|title=Annalen der Gesetzgebung und Rechtsgelehrsamkeit in den preussischen Staaten, Volume 4|year=1796|location=Berlin, Stettin|publisher=Friedrich Nicolai}}</ref>
===Indian Subcontinent=== A long struggle between the [[Sikh]] community and Islamic rulers resulted in [[Martyrdom in Sikhism|execution of Sikhs]]. In 1746, Bhai Subeg Singh and Bhai Shahbaz Singh were executed on rotating wheels.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sikh-history.com/sikhhist/martyrs/shahbaz.html | publisher=www.sikh-history.com | accessdate=11 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.art-heritage.com/historical/historical-paintings/bhai-shahbaz-singh-ms-18.html | title=www.art-heritage.com | accessdate=11 June 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160614073130/http://www.art-heritage.com/historical/historical-paintings/bhai-shahbaz-singh-ms-18.html# | archive-date=14 June 2016 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Scotland=== In [[Scotland]], a servant named Robert Weir was broken on the wheel at [[Edinburgh]] in 1603 or 1604 (sources disagree). This punishment had been used infrequently there. The crime had been the murder of John [[Clan Kincaid|Kincaid]], Lord of [[Warriston]], on behalf of his wife, [[Jean Kincaid]]. Weir was secured to a cart wheel and was struck and broken with the [[Coulter (agriculture)|coulter]] of a [[plough]]. Lady Warriston was later beheaded.<ref>Chambers, Robert (1885). ''Domestic Annals of Scotland''. Edinburgh: W & R Chambers.</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Ancient Ballads and Songs of the North of Scotland |last= Buchan |first= Peter |authorlink= Peter Buchan |volume= 1 |year= 1828 |location= Edinburgh, Scotland |page= 296 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=1h_gAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA296&dq=John+Kincaid+Warriston&cd=1#v=onepage&q=John%20Kincaid%20Warriston&f=false |accessdate= 21 March 2010}}</ref>
===British and French colonial empires=== This method of execution was used in 18th-century North America following slave revolts. It was once used in New York after several British citizens were killed [[New York Slave Revolt of 1712|during a slave rebellion]] in 1712. Between 1730 and 1754, 11 slaves in French-controlled [[Louisiana]], who had revolted against their masters, were killed on the wheel.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.deathpenaltyinfo.org/documents/ESPYstate.pdf | title = Executions in the U.S. 1608–2002: The Espy File | publisher = Death Penalty Information Center | format = PDF | accessdate = 25 February 2010}}</ref>
=== Habsburg Empire === At the end of the [[Revolt of Horea, Cloșca and Crișan]], in 1785 (in the Austrian [[Principality of Transylvania (1711–1867)]]), two of the revolt leaders, Horea and Cloșca, were sentenced to be executed by the breaking wheel. Crișan hanged himself in prison before that sentence could be carried out. According to a book published the same year by Adam F. Geisler, the two leaders were broken "von unten auf", from bottom up, meaning the lower limbs were broken before the upper limbs, prolonging the torture.<ref>{{cite book|last=Geisler|first=Adam F.|page=68|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VvVKAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA68|title=Horja und Klotska, Oberhaupt und Rathgeber der Aufrührer in Siebenbürgen. Ein Beitr. zur Menschenkunde etc|year=1785|publisher=Buchhandl. d. Gelehrten|location=Karlsburg and Hammerstadt}}</ref>
===Russia=== The breaking wheel was frequently used in the [[Great Northern War]] in the early 1700s when the [[Tsardom of Russia]] challenged the supremacy of the [[Swedish Empire]] in northern [[Central Europe]] and [[Eastern Europe]].
===Sweden=== [[Image:Breaking Wheel.jpg|thumb|The execution of [[Peter Stumpp]], involving the breaking wheel in use in Cologne in the early modern period]] [[Johann Patkul]] was a [[Livonian people|Livonian]] gentleman who was condemned on charges of treason by Swedish king [[Charles XII of Sweden|Charles XII]] in 1707. The priest Lorentz Hagen was a friend of Patkul's and described the horrors his friend had to endure when Patkul was condemned to be broken on the wheel:<ref>{{cite book|last=Hagen|first=Lorentz|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=27NbAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA45|pages=45–46|title=Anecdotes Concerning the Famous John Reinhold Patkul: Or, an Authentic Relation of what Passed Betwixt Him and His Confessor, the Night Before and at His Execution. Translated from the Original Manuscript, Never Yet Printed|year=1761|location=London|publisher=A. Millar}}</ref>
{{quote|Here the executioner gave him the first stroke. His cries were terrible. "O Jesus! Jesus, have mercy upon me!" This cruel scene was much lengthened out, and of the utmost horror; for as the headsman had no skill in his business, the wretch under his hands received upwards of fifteen blows, with each of which were intermixed the most piteous groans, and invocations of the name of God. At length, after two strokes given on the breast, his strength and voice failed him. In a faltering dying tone, he was just heard to say, "Cut off my head!" and the executioner still lingering, he himself placed his head on the scaffold: in a word, after four strokes with an hatchet, the head was separated from the body, and the body quartered. Such was the end of the renowned Patkul: and may God have mercy on his soul!}}
===Later use=== The breaking wheel was used as a form of execution in Germany as recently as the early 19th century. Its use as a method of execution was not fully abolished in Bavaria until 1813, and still in use until 1836 in [[Electorate of Hesse|Hesse-Kassel]]. In [[Prussia]], the punishment of death was inflicted by [[decapitation]] with a large sword, by burning, and by breaking on the wheel. At the time, the Prussian penal code required a criminal to be broken upon the wheel when a particularly heinous crime had been committed. The king always issued an order to the executioner to strangle the criminal (which was done by a small cord not easily seen) before his limbs were broken. The last execution by this stronger form of capital punishment, of [[Rudolf Kühnapfel]], was on 13 August 1841.<ref>Blazek, Matthias: „Letzte Hinrichtung durch Rädern im Königreich Preußen am 13. August 1841“ (In the Kingdom of Prussia a criminal was broken upon the wheel for the last time on 13 August 1841), in: Fachprosaforschung – Grenzüberschreitungen. Deutscher Wissenschafts-Verlag (DWV), Baden-Baden, ed. 7, 2011, p. 339–343. {{cite book |title= A Law Dictionary and Glossary |last= Burrill |first= Alexander |authorlink= Alexander Burrill |edition= 2nd |volume= 2 |year= 1870 |publisher= Baker Voorheis and Co. |location= New York, NY |page= 620 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ztgUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA620&lpg=PA620&dq=prussia+1841+breaking+wheel#v=onepage&q=&f=false |accessdate= 21 March 2010}} Rudolf Kühnapfel, [[assassin]] of Andreas Stanislaus von Hatten, the Bishop of [[Warmia]], was sentenced to be executed in this manner, though he was killed by [[strangulation]] before his corpse was broken on the wheel.</ref>
==Archaeology== [[Image:Hinrichtung durch Rädern, Skelett.jpg|right|thumb|Skeletal remains of a man executed by "breaking wheel", aged about 25 to 30 years, from the 16th to 18th century. Discovered in 2014, in the place of execution [[Pöls-Oberkurzheim]] ([[Styria]]), Austria. The skeleton is displayed at [[Riegersburg Castle]] in Austria]] Since victims' bodies of the breaking wheel were often left exposed to environmental influences over a long period of time, so hardly any [[Feature (archaeology)|archaeological features]] for the "breaking wheel" exist; as a deterrence, the bodies were often left on public display over many years, exposed to wind and weather, birds and other scavenging animals could also take away the remains and bones. In the [[List of territorial entities where German is an official language|German-speaking areas]], only one archaeological discovery of a breaking wheel victim has been documented so far: In autumn 2013, the skeleton of a man was found in [[Groß Pankow (Prignitz)|Groß Pankow]], Germany, the sensational find was discovered during the laying of Federal Highway 189 (''Bundesstraße 189'') between [[Perleberg]] and [[Pritzwalk]] in [[Brandenburg]], whose position and signs of injury indicate death by the "breaking wheel".<ref name="FCS1">{{cite web |url=https://www.focus.de/wissen/historischer-fund-in-gross-pankow-erstmals-das-skelett-eines-geraederter-mannes-gefunden_id_3838956.html|title=Historischer Fund in Groß Pankow: Sensation! Skelett eines geräderten Mannes gefunden |trans-title=Historical find in Groß Pankow: Sensation! Skeleton of a wheeled man found |last= |first= |date= |website=FOCUS Online|publisher=FOCUS Online |access-date= |language=German |quote=}}</ref> Based on an iron belt buckle, the skeleton was dated to the 15th to 17th centuries, the identity of the man is unknown.<ref name="FCS1" /> A similar archaeological find has since also been discovered in 2014, in [[Pöls-Oberkurzheim]], [[Styria]], Austria.
==Metaphorical uses== The breaking wheel was also known as a great dishonor, and appeared in several expressions as such. In [[Dutch language|Dutch]], there is the expression ''opgroeien voor galg en rad'', "to grow up for the gallows and wheel," meaning to be destined to come to no good. It is also mentioned in the Chilean expression ''morir en la rueda'', "to die on the wheel," meaning to keep silent about something. The Dutch expression ''ik ben geradbraakt'', literally "I have been broken on the wheel", is used to describe physical exhaustion and pain, like the [[German language|German]] expression ''sich gerädert fühlen'', "to feel wheeled," and the [[Danish language|Danish]] expression "radbrækket" refer almost exclusively to physical exhaustion and great discomfort.
In Finnish ''teilata'', "to execute by the wheel," refers to forceful and violent critique or rejection of performance, ideas or innovations. The German verb ''radebrechen'' ("to break on the wheel") can refer to speaking incorrectly, for example with a strong foreign accent or with a great deal of foreign vocabulary. Similarly, the [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] ''radbrekke'' can be applied to art and language, and refers to use which is seen as despoiling tradition and courtesy, with connotations of willful ignorance or malice. In [[Swedish language|Swedish]], ''rådbråka'' can be used in the same sense as the English idiom "[[:wikt:rack one's brain|rack one's brain]]" or, as in German, to mangle language.<ref>[http://g3.spraakdata.gu.se/saob/show.phtml?filenr=1/223/158.html Svenska Akademiens Ordbok: Rådbråka] (Swedish only) Retrieved 12 December 2011.</ref>
The word {{lang|fr|roué}}, meaning a debauched or lecherous person, is French, and its original meaning was "broken on the wheel." As execution by breaking on the wheel in France and some other countries was reserved for crimes of particular atrocity, ''roué'' came by a natural process to be understood to mean a man morally worse than a "gallows-bird," a criminal who only deserved hanging for common crimes. He was also a leader in wickedness, since the chief of a gang of brigands (for instance) would be broken on the wheel, while his obscure followers were merely hanged. [[Philip II, Duke of Orléans|Philip, Duke of Orléans]], who was regent of France from 1715 to 1723, gave the term the sense of impious and callous debauchee, which it has borne since his time, by habitually applying it to the very bad male company who amused his privacy and his leisure. The ''[[locus classicus]]'' for the origin of this use of the epithet is in the Memoirs of [[Louis de Rouvroy, duc de Saint-Simon|Saint-Simon]].
Another french expression is "rouer de coups", which means giving a severe beating to someone.
In English, the quotation "[[Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?]]" from [[Alexander Pope]]'s "[[Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot]]" is occasionally seen, referring to putting great effort into achieving something minor or unimportant.
==Execution of St. Catherine== [[File:Coa_Illustration_Cross_Of_St_Catherine.svg|thumbnail|150px|Catherine wheel symbol]] [[File:Waldburg-Gebetbuch 096.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Saint [[Catherine of Alexandria]] with a wheel as her attribute]]
Medieval hagiographies, such as the ''[[Golden Legend|Legenda sanctorum]]'', record that [[Catherine of Alexandria|St. Catherine of Alexandria]] was executed on one of these devices for refusing to renounce her Christian belief, which thereafter became known as the ''Catherine wheel'', also used as her [[saint symbolism|iconographic attribute]]. It is said the wheel miraculously broke when she touched it; she was then [[decapitation|beheaded]].<ref name=clugnet>{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03445a.htm|title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: St. Catherine of Alexandria|work=newadvent.org}}</ref> As an attribute it is usually shown broken in a small version beside her, or sometimes as a miniature she holds in her hand; the sword then used is also often shown.
===Coats of arms with Catherine wheels=== [[Image:St-Catherines College Oxford Coat Of Arms (Motto).svg|right|thumb|The college shield of [[St Catherine's College, Oxford]], depicting four breaking wheels]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Kremnica.svg|thumbnail|150px|Coat of Arms of Kremnica displaying the broken Catherine wheel]] ====Persons==== *[[Thomas de Brantingham]] *[[Katherine Swynford]] ====Organizations==== *[[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]] *[[St Catherine's College, Oxford]]
====Places==== *[[Altena]], Germany *[[Goa]], India, when it was in Portuguese possession *[[Hjørring]], Denmark, where Saint Catherine is the patron-saint of the Town. *[[Kaarina]], Finland, [[:File:Kaarinan vaakuna.png|until 2009]] and Piikkiö's union with Kaarina *[[Kremnica]], Slovakia *[[Kuldīga]], Latvia *[[Molsheim]], France *[[Niedererbach]], Germany *[[Prien am Chiemsee]], Germany, where Saint Catherine is the patron saint of the town *[[Sinaai]], Belgium *[[Wachtebeke]], Belgium

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox person |name =Carin du Rietz |image name = |residence =[[Stockholm, Sweden]] |other_names =Karin du Rietz, Catharina du Rietz, Carin Paulin |birth_date =1766 |birth_place =[[Sweden]] |death_date =1788 |death_place =[[Kungsbacka]], Sweden |death_cause =Childbirth |known =First female soldier in the Royal Guard in the guise of a man. |occupation =Soldier in the Royal Guard |spouse =Erik Johan Paulin |children =An infant, born and died 1788 |website = |footnotes = }} '''Carin or Karin (Catharina) du Rietz''' (1766–1788) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] woman who became a soldier at the [[Högvakten|Royal guard]] in the guise of a man. She was the first woman in the Swedish royal guard. Her story was a well known and discussed event in her time, and later regarded to exemplify the vivacious [[Gustav III of Sweden|Gustavian age]]. == Background == The daughter of [[lieutenant]] Carl du Rietz and Eva Cronhjelm, she was described as a woman with the stunning intelligence of an [[Amazons|Amazon]], with power and courage, temperament and beauty, and a "mind of fire". She grew up in a mansion in [[Småland]]. She ran away from home three times; the cause was thought to have been the strictness of her parents combined with the "reading of too many novels". The first time, she reached [[Stockholm]], where she was discovered and captured by her brothers; the second time she escaped to her doting grandparents on [[Värmdön]]. The third time, however, she dressed herself like a man and enlisted in the [[Högvakten|Royal regiment]] at court in Stockholm, as the first female ever. == In the Royal Guard == During her time as a guard soldier, she preserved her male identity through her "female cunning", but as the story goes, she had so many troubles with sexual advances from both women and men that in the end she could see no other solution but to reveal her identity to the king himself before she was discovered in some other way. According to the legend, she stepped forward and fell down before the king one day when he passed a row of soldiers, of which she was one. She then revealed her identity to him. When she did so, the king, [[Gustav III of Sweden|Gustav III]], was highly amused by her story. He allowed her to marry a librarian at the royal court, Erik Johan Paulin. They were both described as very happy about this. Paulin had a priest-education, and the king gave him the post of vicar in [[Kungsbacka]] parish. Carin was related to [[Charlotte Du Rietz]], to whom the monarch had a strong attachment. De Rietz died in [[childbirth]] shortly after the family moved into their new home; her husband and child died soon after. == Context and other examples == Du Rietz was far from the only example of women personating and living as men. The 18 May 1780 an incident was reported in the newspaper as a warning example;
''As a great benefit to the maids of the city, death newly discovered a terrible fraud, which, if it becomes an example, would alarm the fair sex, humiliate the clothing of males and make medical examinations necessary for both engagements and weddings.''
One of the coachmen of the city of [[Linköping]], Petter Cederlöf, had suddenly taken ill and died within ten hours. The woman taking care of the body then discovered that the man was in fact a woman. It was decided to make it public as a warning. Cederlöf had been hired the spring before after having shown all the necessary papers, amused himself with the maids, and finally proposed and engaged himself with a maid from the city. The fiancee was initially devastated over the death of her dear "Petter", but when she was told, it was reported that: ''All her tears have suddenly ceased.'' Many such stories are told, some of them quite famous; [[Gustafva Juliana Cederström]], (1746-1801) was widely known in the country for having served in several professions as a man, and on the opposite side, there was [[Lasse-Maja]], a man dressing himself as a woman. ==See also== * [http://modis.ispras.ru/wikipedia/pic/1039-9.html Related articles on a diagram]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == References == * [http://runeberg.org/sqvinnor/0140.html ]: Digitalized version of ''Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor'' (Notes on Swedish women) by Wilhelmina Stålberg {{sv icon}} * Andersson, Ingvar (red.), Gustavianskt: [1771-1810] : en bokfilm, [Ny utg.], Wahlström & Widstrand, Stockholm, 1979 {{sv icon}} * [http://runeberg.org/sqvinnor/0109.html] {{sv icon}} * Jakob Christensson: Signums svenska kulturhistoria. Gustavianska tiden. (2007) (The Gustavian age) {{sv icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Du Rietz, Carin}} [[Category:1766 births]] [[Category:1788 deaths]] [[Category:Female wartime cross-dressers]] [[Category:LGBT history in Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish soldiers]] [[Category:18th century in LGBT history]] [[Category:18th-century Swedish people]] [[Category:Deaths in childbirth]] [[Category:Gustavian era people]]
